pages.text: While once connected with ours (see $(l:concepts/wild_magic)my history of Wild Magic$()), the Fey is another world entirely. Much power can be found in the Fey, and it is this that empowers many of the great creatures that hail from there.$(br2)Old documents speak of trade and passage, but it is unclear precisely how connected this world was to ours.

There are many rumours and stories that suggest things native to our world actually came from the Fey, but there is much evidence against this.$(br2)$(l:herbs/pereskia)Pereskia$() is often called 'fairy flower', but while it may delight such creatures, it is simply a flower that blossomed with wild magic.$(br2)Those delightful plant-creatures, Sprouts, on the other hand, seem to be descendents of the Fey.

It is thus important to keep an open mind.$(br2)When presented with something 'from the Fey', you should rightfully question it.$(br2)When told a spell derives 'from the Fey', remember wild magic was great before the Order of Druids even existed.$(br2)Even in this, keep an open mind: perhaps, like sprouts, there are other Fey-born things in our world.

pages.name: The Sprout
pages.text: A common example of sentient plant.
